description: Poker quiz question bank for learning GTO strategy

questions.question: You're UTG with AA in a 6-max cash game. What's your action?
questions.explanation: AA is the strongest starting hand. From UTG, you should raise to 2.5-3bb to build the pot while keeping worse hands in. Limping risks giving free cards to speculative hands, and raising too large telegraphs strength and may fold out hands you dominate.

questions.question: You're on the BTN with AKs. UTG raises to 3bb. What's your action?
questions.explanation: AKs is a premium hand that should be 3-bet for value against an UTG raise. A standard 3-bet size is 3x the original raise when in position. This builds the pot with a strong hand and allows you to realize equity with position postflop.

questions.question: You're UTG with 72o. What's your action?
questions.explanation: 72o is statistically the worst starting hand in poker, with poor equity against any reasonable range. From UTG with 8 players behind, this hand has negative expected value and should be folded immediately.

questions.question: You're in the CO with AJo. Everyone folds to you. What's your action?
questions.explanation: AJo is comfortably within the CO opening range. With only the BTN and blinds behind, you have good position and a strong hand. Raising is standard to take initiative and build the pot with a hand that has good equity.

questions.question: You're in the SB with KQo. BTN raises to 2.5bb. What's your action?
questions.explanation: KQo is a strong hand that should be 3-bet from the SB against a BTN open. The BTN has a wide opening range, and 3-betting allows you to take initiative and avoid playing out of position with a capped range. A slightly larger sizing (4x) is used from out of position.

questions.question: You're in the BB with 87s. CO raises to 2.5bb, BTN calls. What's your action?
questions.explanation: 87s is a suited connector with excellent implied odds in multiway pots. You're getting a favorable price (closing the action with good pot odds) and can realize equity well. 3-betting would be too aggressive with this speculative hand, and folding wastes the pot odds you're receiving.

questions.question: You're on the BTN with A5s. UTG raises to 3bb. What's your action?
questions.explanation: A5s is a polarized 3-bet candidate from the BTN. It has ace blockers (reducing the likelihood villain has AA/AK), can make the nut flush, and has wheel potential. This hand is too weak to call but strong enough to 3-bet as a bluff with good postflop playability.

questions.question: You're in the SB with JTs. BTN raises to 2.5bb. What's your action?
questions.explanation: JTs should be 3-bet from the SB against a BTN open. Calling creates a capped range out of position, while 3-betting allows you to take initiative with a hand that has strong postflop equity. This hand can make straights, flushes, and strong top pairs.

questions.question: You're in the BB with QJo. UTG raises to 3bb, MP calls. What's your action?
questions.explanation: QJo is a marginal hand facing an UTG raise and a call. You're out of position against two players with strong ranges. QJo doesn't play well multiway and is dominated by many hands in their ranges (AQ, KQ, QQ, JJ). The pot odds aren't sufficient to overcome the positional and equity disadvantages.

questions.question: You're in the SB with A4s. BTN raises to 2.5bb. What's your action?
questions.explanation: A4s is a premium 3-bet bluff from the SB versus BTN. It has strong ace blockers, nut flush potential, and wheel possibilities. Calling would leave you out of position with a capped range, while 3-betting allows you to win the pot immediately or play for stacks with good equity when called.

questions.question: You're in BB with K9s. SB raises to 3bb (heads up). What's your action?
questions.explanation: In blind versus blind situations, ranges are significantly wider. K9s is strong enough to 3-bet for value against the SB's wide opening range. This hand has good equity, can make strong pairs and flushes, and 3-betting allows you to take control of the pot.

questions.question: You're UTG with 99. What's your action?
questions.explanation: 99 is at the bottom of most UTG opening ranges but should still be opened. It's a strong pocket pair that has good equity against most hands and can win large pots when it improves or holds up. Folding would be too tight, and limping invites multiway pots where your hand value decreases.

questions.question: Is QQ in UTG's opening range?
questions.explanation: QQ is a premium pocket pair and is always in every position's opening range. UTG typically opens all pocket pairs 99+ along with strong broadway hands and suited connectors down to about 65s.

questions.question: Is 65s in UTG's opening range?
questions.explanation: 65s is too speculative for UTG. While suited connectors have playability, they need position and favorable pot odds to be profitable. UTG's range is tight (roughly 12-15% of hands), and 65s doesn't make the cut. This hand becomes profitable from HJ/CO onwards.

questions.question: Is AKo in BTN's opening range?
questions.explanation: AKo is a premium hand that's in every position's opening range. The BTN has the widest opening range (approximately 45-50% of hands) due to positional advantage, and AKo is near the top of that range.

questions.question: Is 22 in UTG's opening range?
questions.explanation: Small pocket pairs like 22 are generally not in UTG's opening range. While some aggressive players might include them, standard UTG ranges start at 99 or 88 at the loosest. Small pairs need implied odds and position to be profitable, which UTG lacks.

questions.question: Is A5s in BTN's 3-bet range vs CO?
questions.explanation: A5s is a standard 3-bet bluff from BTN versus CO. It has ace blockers (reducing AA/AK combos), nut flush potential, and wheel straight possibilities. It's too weak to call but has enough equity and playability to 3-bet profitably.

questions.question: Is KJo in UTG's opening range?
questions.explanation: KJo is not in UTG's opening range. While it's a broadway hand, it's dominated by too many hands in opponents' ranges (AK, AJ, KQ) and doesn't play well out of position. UTG typically only opens KQo+ among offsuit broadway combinations.

questions.question: Is 98s in HJ's opening range?
questions.explanation: 98s is a suited connector that's comfortably within HJ's opening range. HJ opens approximately 20-25% of hands, and 98s has good playability with straight and flush potential. It benefits from the improved position compared to early positions.

questions.question: Is TT in BB's 3-bet range vs UTG?
questions.explanation: TT is typically a call in the BB versus an UTG open, not a 3-bet. BB's 3-bet range versus UTG is polarized and tight, consisting primarily of JJ+, AKs, and AKo for value, plus some bluffs. TT has good equity but is better suited for a calling strategy to realize equity postflop.

questions.question: Is 76s in BTN's 3-bet range vs CO?
questions.explanation: 76s is included in BTN's polarized 3-bet range versus CO as a bluff. Suited connectors make excellent 3-bet bluffs because they have good postflop playability, can make disguised straights and flushes, and don't block hands that would fold to a 3-bet.

questions.question: Is QJo in MP's opening range?
questions.explanation: QJo is not in MP's opening range. MP (Middle Position) still has many players to act behind and needs a relatively tight range. QJo is dominated by many hands and doesn't play well out of position. It becomes a profitable open from HJ onwards where ranges widen.

questions.question: Is ATo in CO's opening range?
questions.explanation: ATo is in CO's opening range. CO opens approximately 25-30% of hands, and ATo has sufficient equity and playability from this position. It can make strong top pairs and has good card removal effects against 3-betting ranges.

questions.question: Is K7s in SB's 3-bet range vs BTN?
questions.explanation: K7s is in SB's 3-bet range versus BTN as a bluff. Against BTN's wide opening range (40-50%), SB needs to defend aggressively. K7s has king blockers, flush potential, and enough equity to 3-bet profitably while avoiding the trap of calling out of position with a weak hand.

questions.question: What hand do you have with Ah Kh on a board of Qh Jh Th 2c 5s?
questions.explanation: You have A-K-Q-J-T all in hearts, which forms a Royal Flush—the absolute best possible hand in poker. This is an unbeatable hand that consists of the highest straight flush.

questions.question: What hand do you have with As Ac on a board of Ad Kh 7c 7s 2d?
questions.explanation: You have three Aces (AAA) and the pair of Sevens on the board (77), making a full house—Aces full of Sevens. This is the best possible hand on this board.

questions.question: What hand do you have with 9s 8s on a board of Ts 7s 6h 2c Kd?
questions.explanation: You have T-9-8-7-6, making a ten-high straight. While you also had a flush draw (four spades), it didn't complete. The straight is your final hand.

questions.question: What hand do you have with Kd Qd on a board of 8d 5d 2h 3d Jc?
questions.explanation: You have five diamonds (K♦ Q♦ 8♦ 5♦ 3♦), making a King-high flush. This is a strong hand that beats all straights, sets, and lower flushes.

questions.question: What hand do you have with Jc Tc on a board of 9c 8c 7h 2s Kd?
questions.explanation: You have J-T-9-8-7, making a Jack-high straight. Although you had a flush draw on the flop (four clubs), it didn't complete. Your straight is still a very strong hand.

questions.question: What hand do you have with 5h 5s on a board of Ah 5d 5c 8s 2d?
questions.explanation: You have all four fives (5♥ 5♠ 5♦ 5♣), making four of a kind—also called quads. This is an extremely strong hand that's very difficult to beat.

questions.question: What hand do you have with 6c 5c on a board of 9c 8c 7c 2h Kd?
questions.explanation: You have 9-8-7-6-5 all in clubs, making a nine-high straight flush. This is the second-best hand type in poker, beaten only by a Royal Flush.

questions.question: You have As 2s on a board of Ks Qs Js 3h 4d. What hand do you have?
questions.explanation: You have the nut flush (A♠ K♠ Q♠ J♠ 2♠). You don't have a Royal Flush because that requires A-K-Q-J-T of the same suit, and you have a 2 instead of a T. Your ace-high flush is still extremely strong.

questions.question: What hand do you have with Th 9h on a board of Jh 8h 7d 6c 2s?
questions.explanation: You have J-T-9-8-7, making a Jack-high straight. While you also have a flush draw with four hearts, it didn't complete. Your straight is the nuts on this board.

questions.question: What hand do you have with Kh Kd on a board of Kc 9s 9h 4d 2c?
questions.explanation: You have three Kings (KKK) and the pair of Nines on the board (99), making a full house—Kings full of Nines. This is the best possible hand on this board.

questions.question: The pot is $100 and villain bets $50. What pot odds are you getting to call?
questions.explanation: You need to call $50 to win $150 (the original pot of $100 plus villain's bet of $50). This gives you pot odds of 150:50, which simplifies to 3:1. You need at least 25% equity to make a profitable call based on direct pot odds alone.

questions.question: The pot is $80 and villain bets $80. What pot odds are you getting to call?
questions.explanation: You need to call $80 to win $160 (the original pot of $80 plus villain's bet of $80). This gives you pot odds of 160:80, which simplifies to 2:1. You need at least 33% equity to make a profitable call.

questions.question: The pot is $200. Villain bets $100. You have a flush draw (9 outs). Should you call on the turn?
questions.explanation: You're getting 3:1 pot odds (need 25% equity). With 9 outs on the turn, you have approximately 18% equity (9 outs × 2% per out). Your direct pot odds aren't sufficient. However, with significant implied odds (if villain will pay you off when you hit), this could become a call. Without implied odds, it's a fold.

questions.question: The pot is $100. Villain bets $25. You have a gutshot straight draw (4 outs). Should you call on the turn?
questions.explanation: You're getting 5:1 pot odds (need 17% equity). With 4 outs on the turn, you have approximately 8% equity based on direct odds. However, you're getting such a good price that with even modest implied odds (the potential to win more on the river), this becomes a profitable call. The 5:1 price is too good to fold.

questions.question: The pot is $150. Villain goes all-in for $150. You have 15 outs (flush draw + straight draw). Should you call on the turn?
questions.explanation: You're getting 2:1 pot odds (need 33% equity). With 15 outs on the turn, you have approximately 30% equity to hit by the river (15 × 2%). While this is slightly below the required 33%, it's close enough that factors like card removal, potential for opponent to have redraws, or slight miscounting of outs could make this profitable. In practice, this is a call.

questions.question: You have a combo draw (flush draw + open-ended straight = 15 outs) on the flop. Pot is $100, villain bets $75. Should you call?
questions.explanation: You're getting approximately 2.3:1 pot odds (need ~30% equity). With 15 outs on the flop, using the rule of 4, you have approximately 60% equity to hit by the river (15 × 4%). Even seeing just the turn, you have ~30% equity. This is a highly profitable call, and you might even consider raising as a semi-bluff.

questions.question: What bet size as a percentage of the pot gives your opponent exactly 2:1 pot odds?
questions.explanation: If the pot is $100 and you bet $100 (pot-sized bet), your opponent must call $100 to win $200 (original pot + your bet), giving them exactly 2:1 pot odds. This requires 33% equity to call profitably. A pot-sized bet is a common sizing to charge draws the maximum while still getting calls from weaker hands.

questions.question: The pot is $200. You bet $100. Villain raises to $400. You have top pair. What odds are you getting to call?
questions.explanation: You need to call $300 more (villain's $400 minus your $100 already invested). The pot will be $700 (original $200 + your $100 + villain's $400). So you're getting 700:300, which is approximately 2.3:1. You need about 30% equity to call. With top pair facing a large raise, you likely don't have sufficient equity and should consider folding.

questions.question: Which position has the tightest opening range in a 6-max game?
questions.explanation: UTG (Under the Gun) has the tightest opening range, approximately 15-18% of hands in 6-max. This is because there are still 5 players left to act who could wake up with strong hands, and UTG will be out of position postflop against most opponents.

questions.question: Which position has the widest opening range in a 6-max game?
questions.explanation: BTN (Button) has the widest opening range, approximately 45-50% of hands. This is because only the blinds remain to act, and the button will have position postflop against all opponents. This positional advantage allows for profitable opens with many marginal hands.

questions.question: From which position do suited connectors like 76s first become profitable to open?
questions.explanation: Suited connectors like 76s typically enter opening ranges around HJ (Hijack) position. Earlier positions require tighter ranges due to more players to act behind and worse position postflop. HJ offers a good balance of fewer players behind and reasonable position.

questions.question: Why is position considered the most important factor in poker?
questions.explanation: Position is valuable because acting last postflop gives you maximum information about opponents' actions before making your decision. This allows you to make more informed decisions, control pot size, bluff more effectively, and extract maximum value from strong hands.

questions.question: What is the approximate opening range percentage for CO (Cutoff) in 6-max?
questions.explanation: CO opens approximately 25-28% of hands in 6-max games. This is wider than HJ (~22%) but tighter than BTN (~48%). CO has good position with only the button and blinds behind, allowing for a reasonably wide but still selective range.

questions.question: In a blind vs blind situation, approximately what percentage of hands should the SB open?
questions.explanation: In blind versus blind situations, the SB should open approximately 50-60% of hands. This is because only one player remains (BB), and the pot odds are favorable. However, SB still has a positional disadvantage postflop, which prevents opening even wider despite the heads-up situation.

questions.question: You raised preflop from CO with AK and got called by BB. Flop comes Q♠ 7♥ 2♣. Should you c-bet?
questions.explanation: This is a dry board that favors your range as the preflop raiser. You should c-bet with your entire range on this texture. A small sizing (33% pot) is optimal because villain's range is capped and you want to bet frequently. AK specifically has good equity with two overcards and can barrel turn cards.

questions.question: You raised from BTN with 9♠8♠ and BB called. Flop is K♣ J♦ 8♥. BB checks. What's your action?
questions.explanation: This board heavily favors BB's calling range, which contains many Kx and Jx hands. Your bottom pair has showdown value but is vulnerable. Checking back allows you to realize equity, control pot size, and avoid facing difficult decisions against raises or turn aggression. Your hand is too strong to fold but too weak to bet for value.

questions.question: You raised UTG with QQ, BTN called. Flop is A♠ K♦ 3♣. What's your action?
questions.explanation: This board is terrible for your hand. While you should c-bet some of your range, QQ specifically should check. The board connects heavily with BTN's calling range (Ax, Kx, broadway hands), and you're behind most hands that continue. Checking allows you to pot control and potentially catch a Q on later streets while avoiding building a large pot out of position with an under-pair.

questions.question: CO opens to 2.5bb. You're on BTN with A♠2♠. What's your action?
questions.explanation: A2s is a premium 3-bet bluff candidate from BTN versus CO. It has strong ace blockers, nut flush potential, and wheel straight possibilities. It's too weak to call (dominated by better aces) but has excellent equity and playability when 3-bet. A standard 3x sizing is appropriate.

questions.question: HJ opens to 2.5bb. You're in CO with 88. What's your action?
questions.explanation: 88 is a borderline hand that plays better as a call than a 3-bet versus HJ. It has good implied odds to stack overpairs when you flop a set, but doesn't fare well when 3-betting and getting called or 4-bet. Calling keeps the pot smaller and allows you to realize your equity more effectively.

questions.question: UTG raises to 3bb, MP calls. You're in BB with A♠J♠. What's your action?
questions.explanation: This is a squeeze spot. AJs is strong enough to 3-bet for value against UTG's opening range and MP's calling range. The squeeze sizing should be larger (4-5x the original raise) due to multiple players and dead money. This puts maximum pressure on both opponents and allows you to take down the pot immediately or play heads-up with initiative.

questions.question: You open CO to 2.5bb with KK. BTN 3-bets to 8bb. What's your action?
questions.explanation: KK is a premium hand that should 4-bet for value against BTN's 3-bet range. A standard 4-bet size is approximately 2.2-2.5x the 3-bet size. This sizing builds the pot while leaving room for further action. Going all-in would be too large and only get called by AA, while calling would be too passive with such a strong hand.

questions.question: You raised BTN with 7♠6♠, BB called. Board runs out K♦ Q♣ 3♠ 2♥ A♠. You missed everything. BB checks river. Pot is 40bb, you have 75bb behind. What's your action?
questions.explanation: This is an excellent bluff spot. The ace on the river is a scare card that improves your perceived range more than BB's. BB has checked three times, indicating weakness. A large bet (75-85% pot) represents a strong hand and puts maximum pressure on BB's marginal holdings. Your hand has no showdown value, so betting is superior to checking back.

questions.question: You open BTN to 2.5bb, BB 3-bets to 10bb. You have 100bb stacks. What is the Minimum Defense Frequency (MDF) for your range here?
questions.explanation: MDF is calculated as Pot / (Pot + Bet). Here, the 'bet' is the additional 7.5bb you must call. The pot is 13bb (2.5 open + 10 3-bet + 0.5 SB). MDF = 13 / (13 + 7.5) = 13 / 20.5 ≈ 63%. However, in practice, because you are in position, your actual defense frequency is slightly lower than pure MDF due to realizeable equity, but ~58-62% is the theoretical baseline for not being exploited by bluffs.

questions.question: UTG opens, you call in the BB. Flop is 4♠ 5♦ 6♣. Why is this a candidate for a 'Donk Bet' range?
options: Because you have the range advantage
Because you have the nut advantage on low/connected textures
To prevent the UTG from checking back
Because you want to build the pot with top pair
questions.answer: Because you have the nut advantage on low/connected textures
questions.explanation: On 4-5-6, the BB has all the sets (44, 55, 66), straights (78s, 32s), and two pairs (54s, 65s) that UTG usually doesn't open. When the caller has a significant 'nut advantage' (more super-strong hands than the aggressor), GTO strategy often incorporates a leading (donk) range to extract value and deny equity immediately.

questions.question: Board is K♥ J♠ 8♦ 5♣ 2♠. You are bluffing the river. Which hand is the best bluffing candidate based on blockers?
questions.explanation: Q-T is an excellent bluff here because it blocks the most likely calling hands: KJ, QJ, JT, and T9 (which made a straight on the turn/river if it was 7-9). A-Q blocks some value but also blocks hands villain might fold (like Q-high air). Q-T specifically targets the 'middle' of villain's range that needs to fold.

questions.question: On a board of Q♥ 7♦ 2♣ 5♠ 3♦, you have 77 (Set). The pot is 20bb. Why might an overbet (150% pot) be superior to a standard 75% pot bet?
options: To polarize your range and maximize value from Qx
Because the board is very draw-heavy
questions.answer: To polarize your range and maximize value from Qx
questions.explanation: On very 'static' boards (where the nuts won't change easily), overbetting allows you to polarize. You either have the nuts or a total bluff. This forces hands like AQ or KQ into a 'bluff-catcher' role where they must decide if you are polarized correctly. It extracts maximum value from the top of their calling range.

questions.question: You call a BTN open in the BB. Flop is A♠ K♥ 2♦. What should your check-raise frequency be on this flop?
questions.explanation: This board is a 'range lock' for the BTN. They have all the AA, KK, AK, and strong Ax. BB has almost no nut advantage. When the aggressor has a massive range and nut advantage, the defender must play very passively, checking almost 100% and raising only the rarest of hands (like 22) to protect the checking range.

questions.question: UTG opens, MP 3-bets. You are in the CO with QQ. Why is a 'Cold 4-bet' often preferred over calling?
options: To see where you are at
To reduce the SPR and prevent being outplayed post-flop
To invite the BTN to over-call
questions.answer: To reduce the SPR and prevent being outplayed post-flop
questions.explanation: Cold calling a 3-bet with QQ is dangerous as it leaves you multi-way and out of position to the 3-better or inviting a squeeze from the BTN/Blinds. Cold 4-betting defines your hand, often wins the pot immediately, and if called, creates a low SPR (Stack-to-Pot Ratio) where QQ is easy to play on most flops.

questions.question: You call a c-bet on J♥ 8♥ 2♣ with Q♠ T♠. The turn is the 2♦. Villain bets again. Why is this a good 'float' or 'semi-bluff' raise candidate?
options: Because you have a flush draw
Because the 2d is a 'blank' that doesn't improve villain's range
Because you block QJ and JT
questions.answer: Because you block QJ and JT
questions.explanation: Floating with Q-T is strong because you have two overcards to the 8 and you block the most likely Jx hands villain is value-betting (QJ, JT). If you raise, you represent the 2 (which BB has more of) and put massive pressure on their Jx hands. Even if called, you have 6-10 outs to improve.

questions.question: In GTO, why is A5s often played as a 3-bet bluff at a specific frequency (e.g., 40%) rather than 100%?
options: To maintain board coverage across different runouts
Because it's only profitable 40% of the time
questions.answer: To maintain board coverage across different runouts
questions.explanation: GTO uses mixed strategies to ensure that your range 'covers' enough boards. If you always 3-bet A5s, your calling range loses those wheel/flush possibilities on low boards. By mixing, you ensure that both your 3-bet range and your calling range remain difficult to play against on any flop.

questions.question: You know a villain C-bets 100% of flops. How should you adjust your check-raising range in the BB?
options: Tighten up and only raise the nuts
Expand your check-raise range to include more high-equity draws and air
questions.answer: Expand your check-raise range to include more high-equity draws and air
questions.explanation: If a villain bets too often, their range is 'wide' and 'weak'. To exploit this, you should increase your check-raise frequency. Since they have so much 'air' in their betting range, they will be forced to fold a large portion of it to a raise, making your bluffs and semi-bluffs immediately profitable.

questions.question: What is 'Geometric Sizing' in the context of a 3-street value plan?
options: Betting the same dollar amount on every street
Betting the same percentage of the pot on every street to be all-in by the river
Increasing the bet size by 2x on each street
questions.answer: Betting the same percentage of the pot on every street to be all-in by the river
questions.explanation: Geometric sizing is the most efficient way to get stacks in. By betting the same % of the pot on flop, turn, and river, you maximize the final pot size while keeping the individual bets as 'small' as possible relative to the pot on each street. It is the GTO baseline for value betting with the nuts.

questions.question: Villain opens UTG, you call on the BTN. Flop is 2♠ 3♦ 7♣. Turn is 8♥. River is J♠. Why is your range considered 'capped' on this river?
options: Because you can't have AA or KK
Because you have too many folds
Because you have the nut flush
questions.answer: Because you can't have AA or KK
questions.explanation: Your range is 'capped' because as the preflop caller, you are assumed to NOT have the strongest hands (AA, KK, QQ, AK) which you would have 3-bet. Therefore, on a runout where those hands are the nuts or near-nuts, the UTG (who is 'uncapped') can use large sizing to pressure your entire range.

questions.question: You have 99 on a board of 8♠ 4♦ 2♣. Why is a large c-bet (75%+) often better than a small one here?
options: To get called by worse pairs
To deny equity to overcards like QJ or KT
questions.answer: To deny equity to overcards like QJ or KT
questions.explanation: On low, dry boards, overcards (like QJ) have about 25% equity against your 99. By betting large, you force them to fold, 'denying' them that 25% share of the pot. If you bet small or check, you allow them to realize their equity for cheap or free, which is a disaster for a vulnerable hand like 99.

questions.question: What does the 'Indifference Principle' state regarding a GTO bluffing frequency?
options: The bluff must be sized to make the opponent's calling range have 0 EV
The hero must not care if they win or lose
The opponent must fold 100% of the time
questions.answer: The bluff must be sized to make the opponent's calling range have 0 EV
questions.explanation: In GTO, you bet with a ratio of value-to-bluffs such that your opponent's 'bluff-catchers' have an Expected Value (EV) of exactly zero. This makes the opponent 'indifferent' between calling and folding, meaning they cannot exploit you regardless of what they choose.

questions.question: How does your C-betting frequency change in a 3-way pot compared to a heads-up pot?
options: It increases because there are more people to fold
questions.explanation: In multiway pots, the 'burden of defense' is shared, but the probability that someone has a strong hand increases exponentially. Your equity is split between more players, and bluffs are much less likely to work. GTO strategy in multiway pots is much more honest and value-heavy.

questions.question: On a board of K♠ Q♦ 7♣ 2♥ 3♠, you are in position. Why might you choose a medium sizing with a hand like K-Ts instead of checking back or overbetting?
options: To merge your range and get called by weaker Kx or Qx
questions.answer: To merge your range and get called by weaker Kx or Qx
questions.explanation: Range merging involves betting 'medium-strength' hands that are too strong to check back but not strong enough to be part of a polarized overbet range. By betting medium, you target the opponent's 'marginal' calling range (like K-5s or QJ) that would check-fold to an overbet but check-call a smaller sizing. This maximizes thin value.

questions.question: In a 6-max GTO solution, why does the SB use a 'Linear' 3-bet range against a BTN open, but a 'Polarized' 3-bet range against an UTG open?
options: Because BTN is weaker than UTG
To maximize fold equity against UTG
Because the SB is out of position and needs to realize equity differently against wide vs tight ranges
Because the rake is higher in small pots
questions.answer: Because the SB is out of position and needs to realize equity differently against wide vs tight ranges
questions.explanation: Against a wide BTN open, SB 3-bets a 'linear' range (the best hands) because many of those hands are ahead of BTN's range and play well post-flop. Against a tight UTG open, SB 3-bets 'polarized' (the very best + specific bluffs) because the 'middle' of the SB range (like AJo or KQo) is dominated by UTG's opening range and prefers to fold or call at a low frequency.

questions.question: Why is K-5s considered a superior 4-bet bluff candidate compared to A-Jo in a BTN vs SB dynamic?
options: Because K-5s has more equity against AA
Because K-5s blocks KK and has better post-flop playability/board coverage
Because A-Jo is too strong to bluff
questions.answer: Because K-5s blocks KK and has better post-flop playability/board coverage
questions.explanation: K-5s is a 'low-frequency' 4-bet bluff in solvers. It blocks KK and Kx value hands in the SB's 3-bet range. Unlike A-Jo, which is often dominated when called, K-5s can flop flushes, straights, and has a 'cleaner' out with the King. It also provides 'board coverage' on low textures where a 4-bet range of only high cards would struggle.

questions.question: What does the 'Alpha' (α) value represent in the context of a river bet sizing?
options: The probability that the hero has the nuts
The minimum frequency an opponent must fold to make a bluff break even
The amount of rake taken from the pot
The hero's win rate in bb/100
questions.answer: The minimum frequency an opponent must fold to make a bluff break even
questions.explanation: Alpha (α) is calculated as Risk / (Risk + Reward). For a pot-sized bet, α = 1 / (1 + 1) = 50%. This means a bluff must work more than 50% of the time to be profitable. Understanding α helps players determine if an opponent is over-folding or under-folding relative to the sizing used.

questions.question: On a monotone flop (e.g., A♠ 8♠ 3♠), why does the pre-flop aggressor's C-bet frequency typically drop to 20-30% in solvers?
options: Because they are afraid of the flush
Because the equity is 'bunched' and the nut advantage is often split or held by the caller
questions.answer: Because the equity is 'bunched' and the nut advantage is often split or held by the caller
questions.explanation: On monotone boards, the 'nut advantage' is extremely sensitive to having the Ace of that suit. Since the caller has many suited hands in their range, they often hold the flush or the nut flush draw as often as the aggressor. This 'equity bunching' makes it dangerous for the aggressor to bet wide, leading to a very polarized and low-frequency betting strategy.

questions.question: You are in the BB, BTN opens, you call. Flop is K♦ 7♠ 2♣. Both check. Turn is 5♦. Why is the BB 'probing' range here often very wide (50%+)?
options: Because the 5d is a good card for the BB
Because the BTN's check on the flop 'caps' their range, indicating they likely don't have a strong King
To prevent the BTN from betting the river
questions.answer: Because the BTN's check on the flop 'caps' their range, indicating they likely don't have a strong King
questions.explanation: When the BTN (aggressor) checks back a King-high flop, they rarely have a strong King or better (which they would c-bet for value/protection). This 'caps' their range. The BB can then 'probe' the turn with a wide range of marginal hands and bluffs to take down the pot or deny equity to the BTN's now-obvious weak holdings.

questions.question: Why might a solver use a 25% pot sizing on a board like 9♠ 8♠ 7♦?
options: To keep the pot small with a vulnerable range
To maximize the frequency of bets while maintaining range equity
Because large bets are always better on wet boards
questions.answer: To maximize the frequency of bets while maintaining range equity
questions.explanation: While 'old school' logic says 'bet big on wet boards,' solvers often bet small (25-33%) to maintain a high betting frequency. On 9-8-7, the ranges are very close in equity. A small bet forces the opponent to continue with many marginal hands, allowing the aggressor to realize equity with their entire range without over-committing when they are behind.

questions.question: In Game Theory, what is a 'Subgame Perfect Equilibrium'?
options: A strategy that only works on the flop
A strategy that is optimal at every node of the game tree, regardless of previous play
A strategy that assumes the opponent is a fish
questions.answer: A strategy that is optimal at every node of the game tree, regardless of previous play
questions.explanation: A Subgame Perfect Equilibrium is a refinement of the Nash Equilibrium. It means that at every possible point in the hand (every 'subgame'), the players are playing optimally relative to the remaining game tree. This is what solvers like PioSolver or GTO+ are attempting to calculate.

questions.question: You open UTG, BTN calls. Flop is J♥ 5♦ 2♣. You c-bet, BTN calls. Turn is 3♠. Why is this a prime 'Overbet' (125%+) card for the UTG?
options: Because the 3s completes the straight for UTG
Because the UTG has a massive nut advantage (AA, KK, QQ, JJ) while the BTN is capped
Because the BTN is likely to have a flush draw
questions.answer: Because the UTG has a massive nut advantage (AA, KK, QQ, JJ) while the BTN is capped
questions.explanation: The 3s is a 'blank' that doesn't help the caller's range. UTG still holds all the overpairs (AA-QQ) and top set (JJ), which the BTN would have 3-bet pre-flop. When you have a significant 'nut advantage' on a static board, overbetting the turn puts the caller's marginal Jx hands in an impossible situation and maximizes value from your monsters.

questions.question: Why do GTO strategies often mix between betting and checking with medium-strength hands?
options: To remain unexploitable by making opponent indifferent
Because medium hands have no clear best action
questions.answer: To remain unexploitable by making opponent indifferent
questions.explanation: GTO mixing exists to make opponents indifferent between their options. If you always bet medium hands, opponents can exploit by folding weak hands and continuing only with better. By mixing, you prevent opponents from having a clearly profitable counter-strategy.

questions.question: In a GTO context, what determines the minimum defense frequency (MDF) when facing a bet?
options: The bet size relative to the pot
questions.answer: The bet size relative to the pot
questions.explanation: MDF = Pot / (Pot + Bet). This ensures you defend enough that villain cannot profit by bluffing with any two cards. For a pot-sized bet, MDF is 50%. For a 1/3 pot bet, MDF is 75%. Your actual hands and position affect HOW you construct that defense, not the frequency itself.

questions.question: At equilibrium, a player's bluffs on the river should make the opponent indifferent to calling with bluff-catchers. What ratio of value bets to bluffs achieves this for a pot-sized bet?
questions.explanation: For a pot-sized bet, opponent gets 2:1 odds (risk 1 pot to win 2 pots). To make them indifferent, you need to bluff 1/3 of the time (33%), so your value:bluff ratio is 2:1. The formula is: bluff% = bet/(bet+pot).

questions.question: On Ah Kd 7c flop, why does the preflop raiser have a significant range advantage over the BB caller?
options: They have significantly more strong Ax and Kx combos
The BB should have 3-bet strong hands
questions.answer: They have significantly more strong Ax and Kx combos
questions.explanation: The preflop raiser's range is uncapped and contains AA, KK, AK, AQ, AJ at high frequency. BB's calling range has fewer of these premium combos (many would 3-bet). This range advantage translates to higher c-bet frequencies and larger sizing being theoretically correct.

questions.question: Which factor most significantly impacts a hand's equity realization in a 3-bet pot?
questions.explanation: Equity realization measures how much of your raw equity you actually capture. Position lets you see opponent actions first and control pot size. Playability (suited connectors vs offsuit hands) affects how often you make strong hands vs marginal ones. A suited connector IP may realize 100%+ of equity while the same hand OOP realizes much less.

questions.question: On a Qh 7h 2c flop in a single-raised pot, why is a small c-bet (25-33%) generally preferred over a large one?
options: Because the board favors the raiser's range and we want to bet wide
To pot control with medium hands
questions.answer: Because the board favors the raiser's range and we want to bet wide
questions.explanation: On dry, high-card boards that favor the preflop raiser's range, small sizing allows you to c-bet a very wide range profitably. You don't need large bets to deny equity on such a static board, and smaller bets let you apply pressure with your entire range while risking less with bluffs.

questions.question: When is an overbet (>pot) most theoretically justified on the river?
options: When you have the nuts and want maximum value
When ranges are polarized and you have nutted hands opponent can't have
When the pot is small relative to stacks
questions.answer: When ranges are polarized and you have nutted hands opponent can't have
questions.explanation: Overbets are justified when your range is polarized (nuts or air) and you hold nutted combos that opponent's range lacks. This 'nut advantage' means opponent must call with bluff-catchers that can never be good against your value. The overbet maximizes value from these spots while making your bluffs more profitable.

questions.question: You have Ad Kd on Kh 8s 4c 2d. Opponent checks. What's the main strategic reason to bet?
options: Protection - deny equity to hands with 3-6 outs
Value - get called by worse Kings
questions.answer: Protection - deny equity to hands with 3-6 outs
questions.explanation: TPTK on a dry board beats most of villain's range but is vulnerable to overcards and gutshots (Ax, Qx, Jx, Tx hands have 3-6 outs). Betting denies this equity. While you also get value from worse Kx, the primary driver on dry boards is denying cheap cards to hands that could outdraw you.

questions.question: IP on river after betting flop and turn, villain check-raises all-in for 1.5x pot. You have top two pair on a 4-flush board. What's the key consideration?
options: Whether villain is capable of bluffing
How your hand blocks or unblocks villain's value and bluff combos
questions.answer: How your hand blocks or unblocks villain's value and bluff combos
questions.explanation: Against a polarized river shove, blocker analysis is crucial. Do you block flushes (reducing villain's value combos)? Do you unblock missed draws they'd bluff with? Two pair without a flush card unblocks all flushes (bad) but also unblocks missed straight draws (good for calling). The math depends heavily on these blockers.

questions.question: Why do solvers often check back the nut flush draw on the flop when IP in position?
options: To protect checking range and realize equity with a hand that plays well across all runouts
Because betting would be too transparent
questions.answer: To protect checking range and realize equity with a hand that plays well across all runouts
questions.explanation: Strong draws like nut flush draws have great equity realization when checked - they win big pots when completing and can bluff or value bet turns effectively. By checking some, you protect your checking range (can have strong hands when you check) and avoid building pots OOP can check-raise you off your equity.

questions.question: Why is the BTN opening range significantly wider than UTG despite both being 'opening' situations?
options: BTN has fewer players to act behind
BTN has position postflop against the blinds
BTN can see more flops cheaply
questions.explanation: BTN benefits from both factors: fewer players behind means lower chance of facing a premium hand, AND guaranteed position postflop against the blinds who must act first on every street. This combination means hands that would be losing opens from UTG become profitable from BTN.

questions.question: In a 3-bet pot OOP as the 3-bettor, why do solvers often prefer checking entire range on many flops?
options: Because OOP cannot effectively bet-fold or bet-call against raises
Because 3-bet pots are usually all-in preflop
questions.answer: Because OOP cannot effectively bet-fold or bet-call against raises
questions.explanation: OOP in 3-bet pots, you face a dilemma when raised: bet-folding wastes value with good hands, bet-calling builds pots OOP with capped ranges. Checking transfers initiative to IP but lets you check-raise strong hands and check-call draws, playing more effectively despite positional disadvantage.

questions.question: You open CO, BTN calls, blinds fold. On J72r flop, why can you c-bet at high frequency with small sizing?
options: You have more overpairs and big cards in range
BTN's calling range is capped (would 3-bet premiums)
Both A and B combined with positional advantage
The board is too dry to check
questions.answer: Both A and B combined with positional advantage
questions.explanation: Your opening range has more JJ+, AJ, KJ. BTN's flat range is capped - they'd 3-bet QQ+, AK. Combined with your positional parity (both IP vs blinds who folded), you have range advantage on this high card board. Small sizing lets you bet wide and apply consistent pressure.

questions.question: When constructing a 4-bet bluffing range, which hand type is generally preferred?
questions.explanation: Suited Ax blockers reduce combos of AA and AK in villain's continuing range (they'd 5-bet or call). They have decent equity when called due to nut flush potential and wheel possibilities. Small pairs have poor playability if called, suited connectors don't block premiums, and offsuit broadways have the worst qualities of both.

questions.question: You 3-bet from SB vs BTN open. BTN 4-bets. With AKo, why might folding sometimes be correct despite hand strength?
options: AKo has poor equity against 4-bet range
You block AA/KK/AK that would 4-bet, so villain's range is weighted toward QQ/JJ you flip against
questions.answer: You block AA/KK/AK that would 4-bet, so villain's range is weighted toward QQ/JJ you flip against
questions.explanation: Counterintuitive but AKo blocking AA/KK/AK means villain's 4-bet range is more weighted toward QQ/JJ (where you flip) and bluffs you dominate. In theory this is fine, but rake and OOP disadvantage can make it a fold. AKs with better equity realization changes the math toward calling or 5-betting.

questions.question: UTG opens, you have JTs on the BTN. What's the strongest argument for calling rather than 3-betting?
options: JTs doesn't have enough equity to 3-bet
You keep UTG's weaker hands in that would fold to 3-bet
questions.answer: You keep UTG's weaker hands in that would fold to 3-bet
questions.explanation: JTs plays great postflop with position. 3-betting folds out hands like KJo, QTs, 77 that you dominate or have great implied odds against. Flatting keeps these in, lets you realize your equity with position, and maintains a balanced calling range on BTN. You make money postflop against their mistakes.

questions.question: Why should BB's 3-bet bluffing range vs BTN open be weighted toward suited hands with blockers?
options: They need the equity for when called, and blockers reduce folds they induce
BTN will fold more to suited hand 3-bets
questions.answer: They need the equity for when called, and blockers reduce folds they induce
questions.explanation: BB 3-bet bluffs need suitedness for equity realization when called (flush potential). Blockers like A5s block AA/AK that would 4-bet, increasing fold equity. The combination of fold equity (blockers), equity when called (suitedness), and playability makes these optimal bluff candidates over random weak hands.

questions.question: What is 'range merging' and when is it strategically applied?
options: Combining your value and bluff ranges
Betting medium-strength hands for thin value/protection instead of polarizing
Mixing frequencies with all hand types
questions.answer: Betting medium-strength hands for thin value/protection instead of polarizing
questions.explanation: Range merging means betting hands like second pair or weak top pair that are 'too good to bluff, too weak for thick value.' It's strategically useful against opponents who overcall (you get thin value) or on boards where checking risks giving free cards. It's an exploitative adjustment from pure GTO polarization.

questions.question: In a MW pot where you're the preflop raiser, why is having an 'uncapped' range strategically powerful?
options: You can credibly represent the nuts on any board, forcing opponents to play defensively
You have more hands in your range
You win more often at showdown
questions.answer: You can credibly represent the nuts on any board, forcing opponents to play defensively
questions.explanation: An uncapped range contains the strongest hands (AA, KK, sets, etc). Callers' ranges are often capped - they'd have raised with premiums. This lets you apply pressure on any board since opponents know you COULD have the nuts. They must play defensively, folding hands that might actually be best.

questions.question: You have a flush draw (9 outs) on the flop. Villain bets pot. Why is calling still often correct despite needing ~35% equity and only having ~36%?
options: Implied odds - you'll win more when you hit
questions.answer: Implied odds - you'll win more when you hit
questions.explanation: Raw pot odds give you barely enough equity (~36% vs 35% needed), but implied odds make it clearly profitable. When you hit the flush, you'll often win additional bets. If stacks are deep and opponent likely pays off flushes, your effective odds are much better than the immediate pot odds suggest.

questions.question: Villain overbets 2x pot on river. What equity do you need to call profitably?
questions.explanation: Pot odds = Call / (Pot + Call) = 2 / (1 + 2 + 2) = 2/5 = 40%. You're risking 2x pot to win the 1x pot plus villain's 2x bet. Against a polarized range, this means villain needs to be bluffing less than 40% of the time for a call to be profitable with a bluff-catcher.

questions.question: You have AA on Kh Qh Jh 8d 2c river. Why has your hand strength decreased significantly despite having an overpair?
options: Four to a flush and four to a straight are possible, and many made hands beat you
questions.answer: Four to a flush and four to a straight are possible, and many made hands beat you
questions.explanation: On this board, any heart makes a flush, any T or 9 makes a straight. AT, T9, KQ, KJ, QJ all beat you, and even Kx hands are ahead. Your absolute hand (overpair) is strong, but your relative hand strength against likely continuing ranges is very weak. This is why board reading is crucial.

questions.question: Why is bottom set often played more aggressively than top set on a coordinated board?
options: Top set is better for trapping
Bottom set blocks fewer draws and straight combos that continue
There's no difference in optimal play
questions.answer: Bottom set blocks fewer draws and straight combos that continue
questions.explanation: On a board like JT7, if you have 77 (bottom set), you don't block JT, J7, T7 two pairs or T9, 98, 89 straight draws that might continue. With JJ, you block JT and J7 combinations. Bottom set gets more action from worse hands and thus can bet larger for value while also needing to charge draws more.

questions.question: You open BTN with Ah 5h, BB calls. Flop: Kd 8c 3s. BB checks. What's your play?
questions.explanation: This dry, disconnected board favors your range heavily. A small c-bet with your entire range is effective - you have backdoor nut flush draw and overcard outs. Small sizing puts pressure on BB's weak pairs and high cards while risking little with your air.

questions.question: You open CO with Qh Jh, BB calls. Flop: 9h 8h 2c. BB checks. What's your play?
questions.explanation: You have a monster draw - flush draw plus gutshot to the nuts (15 outs twice). On this wet, connected board you want to build the pot. Larger sizing is appropriate as you have great equity and want to get stacks in by the river. Checking this draw would be a significant mistake.

questions.question: You open UTG with Ad Kd, BTN calls, BB calls. Flop: Jc 7c 4d. BB checks. What's your play?
questions.explanation: In a 3-way pot on a wet board that doesn't favor your UTG range, checking is correct. You have two overcards but no backdoors and the board hits the callers' ranges well. C-betting into multiple opponents with pure air on a connected board is burning money.

questions.question: You 3-bet BTN vs CO with Ac Qc, CO calls. Flop: Kh 7s 2d. CO checks. What's your play?
questions.explanation: As the 3-bettor you have significant range advantage on this dry board. A small c-bet with your entire range is profitable - villain must defend wide but you can barrel effectively when you improve. AQ has backdoor equity and blocks AK.

questions.question: You defend BB with Jc 9c vs BTN open. Flop: Jh 5s 2d. You check, BTN bets 33%, you call. Turn: 8c. You check, BTN bets 75%. What's your play?
questions.explanation: You have top pair decent kicker with a backdoor flush draw. BTN's larger turn sizing polarizes their range. J9 is squarely in your bluff-catching range - folding is too weak (you beat all bluffs) and raising turns your hand into a bluff unnecessarily. Call and evaluate river.

questions.question: You defend BB with 6h 5h vs CO open. Flop: 9d 7c 2h. Check, CO bets 33%, you call. Turn: Kh. Check, CO bets 66%, you call. River: 3s (board: 9d 7c 2h Kh 3s). CO bets 100% pot. What's your play?
questions.explanation: You made a straight on the river. The question is whether to raise for value. Against a 100% pot bet on a 4-straight board, villain is extremely polarized. If they have a straight, you chop. If they have a higher straight (T8), you lose. Raising only gets called by hands that beat or chop with you. Calling captures max value against their bluffs.

questions.question: You open BTN with As Ks, BB 3-bets, you call. Flop: Qh 8c 4d. BB bets 33%, you call. Turn: 2s. BB bets 75% pot. What's your play?
questions.explanation: You have two overcards and a backdoor flush draw, but against BB's 3-bet range that's double-barreling 75% on a dry board, you're in bad shape. BB's value range (QQ, AA, KK, AQ) crushes you, and AK with no pair and limited equity is not a profitable call. Your draws are weak - folding is correct.

questions.question: You defend BB with Kh 9h vs CO open. Flop: Kc 6s 3d. You check, CO checks. Turn: Tc. You bet 50% pot, CO calls. River: 2h. What's your sizing?
questions.explanation: You have top pair with a reasonable kicker. CO checked flop (capped range) but called turn (has something). Your hand is ahead of their calling range (Tx, 6x, draws that missed). Bet for value - 66% extracts from worse kings and tens while not over-committing against the occasional slow-played two pair.

questions.question: You defend BB with 7h 6h vs BTN open. Flop: 8h 5h 2c. You check, BTN bets 33%. What's your play?
questions.explanation: You have an open-ended straight flush draw (15 outs twice). This is an ideal check-raise candidate - you have massive equity, fold equity against BTN's wide c-bet range, and can comfortably stack off if raised. Flat calling is fine but misses value and protection from overcards.

questions.question: You defend BB with Ac 4c vs CO open. Flop: As 7s 4d. You check, CO bets 66%. What's your play?
questions.explanation: Two pair is strong but check-raising here is a mistake. The board is wet with a flush draw - if you check-raise, CO folds all worse hands and continues with better (sets, AK, AQ, flush draws with equity). Your hand plays better as a call to let CO bluff turns and extract value from weaker aces.

questions.question: You open CO with Ks Qs, BB calls. Flop: Kh 9c 5d. You bet 33%, BB calls. Turn: Jh (bringing flush draw). What's your play?
questions.explanation: You have top pair second kicker on a board that just got wetter. Betting for value and protection is correct - BB's calling range includes Kx worse kicker, Jx, 9x, and flush draws. A larger sizing charges draws appropriately while still getting called by worse made hands.

questions.question: You open BTN with 5c 5d, BB calls. Flop: Qh 7c 5h. You bet 33%, BB calls. Turn: Th. What's your play?
questions.explanation: You have bottom set but the turn completes the flush. If BB has the flush, you're drawing to one out. By checking, you control pot size and let BB bet their flushes and bluff with missed draws. If checked through, you can value bet river safely. Betting into a completed flush draw risks losing maximum when behind.

questions.question: You defend BB with Td 9d vs BTN open. Flop: Tc 7s 3d. Check, BTN bets 50%, you call. Turn: 2h. Check, BTN checks. River: 6c. What's your play?
questions.explanation: BTN's turn check caps their range - they'd barrel most overpairs and strong Tx. Your top pair is now likely best. Value bet to extract from 7x, pocket pairs 88-99, and Ax that might call light. 66% is good sizing to get value from medium-strength hands.

questions.question: You 3-bet CO vs BTN with Ah Kh, BTN calls. Flop: Qc Jc 5h. You bet 33%, BTN calls. Turn: 4d. You bet 66%, BTN calls. River: 8s. Pot is 35bb, you have 55bb behind. What's your play?
questions.explanation: You have ace high with no showdown value. But you've told a story of strength with two barrels. BTN's calling range is capped - they'd raise sets and two pair on the wet flop/turn. They likely have Qx, Jx, or a missed draw. An overbet shove is a powerful bluff that pressures all one-pair hands. Your blockers to AQ/KQ add fold equity.

questions.question: You have Ad Ah on Kc 4s 2d against a BB caller. Why is small c-bet sizing (25-33% pot) optimal here?
options: Your range advantage allows high frequency small bets
questions.answer: Your range advantage allows high frequency small bets
questions.explanation: On dry, disconnected boards where the preflop aggressor has significant range advantage (more AA, KK, AK, etc.), small sizing with high frequency is optimal. You can profitably bet your entire range - both value and air - because villain must defend wide against the small bet but you're value betting a wider portion than normal.

questions.question: On Qh Jh Tc as the BTN 3-bettor, why might you prefer checking your entire range over c-betting?
options: The board is too wet to bet
BB's range hits this board as well or better than yours
You don't have any value hands
questions.answer: BB's range hits this board as well or better than yours
questions.explanation: This monotone, connected board hits BB's cold-calling range extremely well - they have all the suited connectors, QJ, JT, QT, and flush draws. As the 3-bettor, while you have overpairs, BB has more two-pair, straights, and made flushes. Without a significant range advantage, the correct strategy is to check your entire range and play a smaller pot.

questions.question: UTG opens 2.5bb, you're in MP with JJ. What's your standard play?
questions.explanation: JJ vs UTG open in MP is a standard flat. 3-betting turns your hand into a bluff against UTG's strong range and you'll face difficult decisions vs 4-bets. By flatting you keep UTG's weaker hands in, maintain a playable SPR, and can set-mine effectively with position on the blinds.

questions.question: CO opens 2.5bb, BTN 3-bets to 8bb, you're in SB with QQ. What's your play?
questions.explanation: QQ is too strong to flat OOP in a 3-bet pot - you'll face difficult postflop decisions without the initiative. 4-betting extracts value from BTN's 3-bet bluffs and worse value hands (JJ, TT, AQ). Size around 2.5x the 3-bet when OOP to deny equity and set up a comfortable SPR.

questions.question: BTN opens 2.5bb, SB folds, you're in BB with 9h 8h. What's your play at 100bb effective?
questions.explanation: 98s is a mandatory 3-bet from BB vs BTN at 100bb. You have a hand that plays terribly postflop OOP when flatting - you'll be check-folding most flops. By 3-betting, you win the pot immediately often (BTN folds ~50%), and when called you have good equity and playability. This is a key defend from modern BB strategy.

questions.question: You open HJ with Ad Td, CO 3-bets to 9bb, BTN cold-calls. What's your play?
questions.explanation: Facing a 3-bet with a cold-caller behind is one of the worst spots in poker. BTN's cold-call range is incredibly strong (QQ+, AK typically). Your AT suited, while decent, is dominated by both ranges and you'll be playing a bloated pot multiway OOP. Clear fold despite the suited broadway.

questions.question: Which hand should NOT be in your BTN vs BB 3-bet calling range at 100bb?
questions.explanation: QJo lacks the playability needed to call 3-bets - it makes dominated top pairs, has no backdoor flushes, and poor straight potential. KQs/JTs have suited playability, A5s has nut flush potential and blocks AA/AK. Offsuit broadways without nutted potential should be folded to 3-bets.

questions.question: When constructing your BTN 4-bet bluffing range vs BB 3-bet, which hands are ideal?
questions.explanation: Suited wheel aces are the ideal 4-bet bluff candidates. They block AA/AK (your opponent's strongest holdings), have nut flush potential when called, and can make unexpected straights. Low pairs have poor blockers and playability, suited connectors lack blockers, offsuit broadways are too easily dominated.

questions.question: You have a flush draw on the turn. Pot is 20bb, villain bets 15bb. What equity do you need to call profitably?
questions.explanation: You need to call 15bb to win 35bb (20bb pot + 15bb bet). Pot odds = 15/35 = 43%. With ~9 flush outs you have roughly 18% equity, so a naked flush draw cannot call. You'd need additional outs (overcards, straight draws) or significant implied odds to continue.

questions.question: Villain shoves 50bb into a 30bb pot on the river. You have a bluff catcher. How often must villain be bluffing for a call to be profitable?
questions.explanation: You must call 50bb to win 80bb (30bb pot + 50bb bet). Required equity = 50/80 = 62.5%. This means villain needs to be bluffing ~63% of the time for a call with a bluff catcher. This is why large river overbets are so powerful - they require extreme bluff frequencies to call profitably.

questions.question: Why is flatting a CO open from the BTN with AQo better than 3-betting at 100bb deep?
options: You want to keep the pot small with a marginal hand
Flatting keeps CO's weaker hands in and you realize equity well IP
questions.answer: Flatting keeps CO's weaker hands in and you realize equity well IP
questions.explanation: AQo is actually strong enough to 3-bet, but flatting is often preferred BTN vs CO because: 1) You have position and can realize equity perfectly postflop 2) 3-betting folds out hands you dominate (KQ, QJ, AT) 3) CO's 4-bet range dominates you heavily. With position, keeping SPR manageable lets you play a profitable postflop game.

questions.question: In a 3-bet pot OOP as BB vs BTN, why should your c-bet frequency be much lower than IP?
options: You have fewer strong hands OOP
BTN has position and can float/raise effectively, punishing frequent c-bets
The pot is too large to risk chips
questions.answer: BTN has position and can float/raise effectively, punishing frequent c-bets
questions.explanation: When you c-bet OOP, BTN can float with position and realize equity on later streets or raise to put you in tough spots. They can also call in position with a wide range knowing they'll outplay you postflop. Therefore, OOP c-betting should be more polar - strong hands and specific bluffs - rather than the high-frequency approach used when IP.

questions.question: If villain's river bet sizing means you need 40% equity to call, and you estimate their bluff-to-value ratio is 1:2, should you call with a pure bluff catcher?
questions.explanation: If villain has a 1:2 bluff-to-value ratio, they're bluffing 33% of the time and value betting 67%. Your bluff catcher has 0% equity vs value and 100% vs bluffs, so your equity = 33%. Since 33% < 40% required, folding is correct. Villain is not bluffing enough to make calling profitable.

questions.question: What is 'removal effect' and why does holding As matter when bluffing on a spade-completed board?
options: As removes nut flush combos from villain's range, making them more likely to fold
As has no effect on bluffing frequency
questions.answer: As removes nut flush combos from villain's range, making them more likely to fold
questions.explanation: When you hold the As on a spade-completed board, you block the nut flush. This means villain cannot have the nuts, making their continuing range weaker on average. They're more likely to have medium flushes or bluff catchers that can fold to aggression. This 'card removal' or 'blocker' effect makes hands with the As better bluff candidates.

questions.question: You 3-bet SB vs BTN with Kd Kc. Flop: Ah 9s 4c. If you plan to triple barrel, what's the best flop sizing?
questions.explanation: On an A-high board in a 3-bet pot, small sizing is best. Your range is polarized (AA/AK value, and KK/QQ blockers/bluffs). Small sizing allows you to bet your entire range profitably and set up efficient turn/river barrels. By using 25-33% flop, 50% turn, and 75-100% river, you maximize fold equity over three streets while risking minimal chips.

questions.question: You have Ac Kc in a single raised pot IP. Board runs out 8c 6c 2d - 4h - Jd. You bet flop and turn, checked to on river. What's your play with this missed draw?
questions.explanation: You have zero showdown value with AK high. However, you've represented strength on two streets and the J on the river changes nothing. A large overbet puts maximum pressure on villain's one-pair hands (8x, 6x, pocket pairs). Your nut blockers (Ac blocks nut flush draws that got there) make this an ideal bluff candidate. Small bets just let villain call with their entire range.

questions.question: You defend BB with Qc Jh vs CO open. Board: Qs 7h 3c 8d 2d. CO checks through turn, river checks to you. What's your play?
questions.explanation: CO's two checks severely cap their range - no Qx would typically check twice. Your top pair is almost certainly best. Value bet confidently against their small pairs, ace-highs, and floats. 66% pot extracts value from hands willing to call while not over-representing your hand strength.

questions.question: You 3-bet BTN vs CO with Ah Jh, CO calls. Board: Jc 8s 4d 2c Kh. You c-bet flop, CO calls. Turn goes check-check. River brings Kh. What's your play?
questions.explanation: The K is a terrible river for your hand. CO's flop-calling range includes all Kx (KQ, KT, K9s) that now beat you. Your AJ with second pair is no longer ahead of villain's perceived calling range. Betting turns your hand into a bluff that doesn't have enough fold equity vs Kx. Check and realize showdown value when you're ahead.

questions.question: Which flop texture most favors the BB caller against a BTN open?
questions.explanation: Connected, wet boards with middle cards favor the BB caller's range. BB defends with suited connectors (QJ, JT, T9, 98, 87) and suited aces with clubs - all of which smash JT9cc. The BTN's range is wider with more random hands and fewer specific combinations. On Kh 4d 4c or As Kh 7c, BTN has significant overpair and top pair advantages.

questions.question: On a monotone flop (e.g., 9h 6h 3h), why should the preflop raiser's c-bet frequency decrease dramatically?
options: The board is too scary to bet
Both players have similar flush frequencies but villain has more calling range equity
You should always check monotone boards
questions.answer: Both players have similar flush frequencies but villain has more calling range equity
questions.explanation: On monotone boards, both players have similar made flush frequencies. However, the caller's range is condensed with more suited hands (part of calling requirements) while the raiser has many offsuit combos. The caller's equity advantage plus draw-heavy board means c-betting becomes unprofitable with a wide range.

questions.question: You open BTN with 9s 9c, BB calls. Flop: Kc 7h 4s. BB donk bets 75% pot. What's your play?
questions.explanation: Donk bets are often polarized - either very strong (sets, two pair) or weak (draws, probes). Your 99 beats all the weak portion but loses to the value. Folding is too tight - you beat 77, 44, and all bluffs. Raising isolates yourself against the top of their range. Calling lets you evaluate turn and realize equity against their bluffs.

questions.question: You defend BB with As 8s vs CO open. Flop: Ac Kd 7c. You check, CO bets 33%, you call. Turn: 3h. You check, CO checks. River: 9c. What's your play?
questions.explanation: CO's turn check is very telling - most Ax and Kx would continue betting for value and protection. Their range is now capped at middle pairs, weak draws, and floats. Your A8 is likely best against this range. Value bet to extract from their showdown-bound hands like 88-TT, 7x, or Kx that gave up.

questions.question: You open UTG with Ah Ad, CO calls, BB calls. Flop: 7c 6c 5c. BB checks. What's your play?
questions.explanation: This is a nightmare board for AA despite being an overpair. The 765 monotone connects with calling ranges heavily - any suited connector, suited one-gapper, and club hands all crush this board. You're multiway and your opponents' ranges hit better than yours. Checking allows pot control and lets you realize equity when safe cards fall.

questions.question: You 3-bet CO vs UTG open with Ks Qs. UTG calls. Flop: As 9s 4d. UTG checks. What's your play?
questions.explanation: You have the second nut flush draw with two overcards. Against UTG's checking range (weaker Ax, underpairs, draws), a small c-bet generates immediate fold equity while building the pot for when you hit. You have ~50% equity vs calling range and can barrel turns that improve you or look scary.

questions.question: You defend SB vs BTN open with 7h 7c. Flop: Ad Kh 7d. You check, BTN bets 33%, you raise to 3x, BTN calls. Turn: Qd (completing flush). What's your play?
questions.explanation: The Qd is a disaster card - it completes the flush and gives BTN possible straights (JT). Your bottom set has zero redraw and faces significant reverse implied odds. If you bet and get raised, you're in a terrible spot. By checking, you control the pot and can call a reasonable bet or check-call river, minimizing loss vs flushes while extracting value from Kx, Qx.

questions.question: You open CO with Jd Td, BTN calls. Flop: 8d 7c 3d. You c-bet 33%, BTN raises to 3x. What's your play?
questions.explanation: You have a flush draw (9 outs) plus a gutshot (3 more outs) plus two overcards (potential 6 more outs) - a monster draw with ~45% equity. But 3-betting risks getting blown off your equity by a jam. Calling keeps you in with implied odds - when you hit, you'll stack weaker flushes and straights. Your hand plays well as a call.

questions.question: BTN opens, you call BB with Ac Tc. Flop: Ks 8h 4c. Check, BTN bets 33%, you call. Turn: 3c. Check, BTN bets 66%, you call. River: 2d. Check, BTN bets 150% pot. What's your play?
questions.explanation: Despite having a bluff catcher, the 150% pot overbet requires villain to be bluffing ~60% of the time for a call to be profitable. BTN's triple barrel line with an overbet is extremely value-heavy. Your Ac blocks some flush draws they'd bluff with, but this reduces your fold equity without improving your calling equity. Against balanced players, this is a fold.

questions.question: You 3-bet BTN vs CO with Ah Qh, CO calls. Flop: Js Tc 4h. You c-bet 33%, CO calls. Turn: 3d. You bet 66%, CO calls. River: 2c. You check, CO bets 80% pot. You have 70bb behind, pot is 35bb. What's your play?
questions.explanation: Your check showed weakness after two barrels. CO's bet could be thin value (Jx, Tx) or turning a hand like KQ/A9s into a bluff. AQ beats all bluffs and many thin value bets. Folding AQ high is too weak given your range has many Ax combos here. Check-raising is unnecessary as you can't be called by worse.

questions.question: You open CO with Kh Qh, BTN calls. Flop: Jc 8c 5s. You check, BTN checks. Turn: Kd. What's your play?
questions.explanation: The turn K improved you to top pair and is a great delayed c-bet card. BTN checked back the flop with a capped range - they don't have AA/KK/JJ typically. Your top pair is ahead of their range. Bet for value and protection against their floats, 8x, and pocket pairs that might outdraw you.

questions.question: You open BTN with 8h 7h, BB calls. Flop: Ac Kd 3s. You check, BB checks. Turn: 9c. BB checks. What's your play?
questions.explanation: Both players checked a dry flop. BB's check on the turn shows extreme weakness - they likely have small pairs or complete air. A delayed c-bet here folds out their 22-TT type hands that beat you and might even get called by worse (Qx floats). You picked up a gutshot and this is a good spot to attack weakness.

questions.question: CO opens, you call BTN with Qc Jc. Flop: 9h 6s 2d. CO c-bets 33%, you call. Turn: Th. CO checks. What's your play?
questions.explanation: CO's turn check signals weakness - most overpairs and top pairs would continue. The T gives you a gutshot straight draw and overcards. Betting puts pressure on their capped range (weak pairs, AK/AQ type hands) and can win the pot immediately. If called, you have 4 outs to the nuts plus possible overcard outs.

questions.question: CO opens, you call BTN with 6s 5s. Flop: Kh 9c 3d. CO bets 33% pot. What's your play?
questions.explanation: Floating requires equity when called on later streets or strong bluffing potential. 65s has no backdoor draws on this board and no overcards. The K-high dry board hits CO's range well. Without any equity or credible turn/river bluff story, folding this low equity hand is correct.

questions.question: CO opens, you call BTN with 7h 6h. Flop: Ks Jc 4h. CO bets 33% pot. What's your play?
questions.explanation: Unlike 65s on K93, here you have backdoor flush draw plus backdoor straight potential. The small c-bet is easy to float with position. On any heart turn you have a draw, on any 5 or 8 you have OESD. You can bluff when CO shows weakness or realize your equity when you improve.

questions.question: You 3-bet SB vs BTN with Ad Kd, BTN calls. Flop: Kh 8s 3c. You bet 33%, BTN calls. Turn: 6d. You bet 66%, BTN calls. River: 2h. Pot is 30bb, you have 60bb behind. What's your play?
questions.explanation: You have top pair top kicker on a dry runout. BTN called two streets - their range is Kx, 88, slow-played 33, or stubborn floats. Your AK beats all Kx except KK (unlikely as they'd often 4-bet pre). Value bet large to extract from KQ, KJ, KT. The 75% sizing keeps their Kx calling while not over-committing vs sets.

questions.question: You defend BB with 6c 5c vs BTN open. Flop: 7c 4c 2h. Check, BTN bets 50%, you call. Turn: 8c (you make flush). Check, BTN bets 66%, you call. River: Ac (4 clubs on board). What's your play?
questions.explanation: The Ac river is disastrous for your small flush. Any club in BTN's hand now makes a flush, and Axcc holdings beat you. If you bet, BTN folds all worse and raises all better. By checking, you induce bluffs from missed draws and can call reasonable bets from worse flushes that fear your check means the Ac. Your 6-high flush becomes a bluff catcher.

questions.question: You're on the river heads-up. The pot is 100bb. You can either check or bet 50bb. What bluff-to-value ratio should your betting range have to be theoretically balanced?
questions.explanation: For a half-pot bet, opponent must call 50 to win 150, needing 33% equity. To make them indifferent, you should bluff 33% of your betting range. This means 1 bluff for every 2 value bets (1:2 ratio = 33% bluffs). This way, calling and folding with bluff catchers have the same EV.

questions.question: Against a balanced opponent on the river, the pot is 10bb and they bet 10bb. What's the maximum frequency you can fold a bluff catcher?
questions.explanation: For a pot-sized bet, you need 50% equity to call (call 10 to win 20). A balanced opponent bets value:bluff at 2:1, meaning they bluff 33% of the time. Your bluff catcher has 33% equity on average - less than the 50% needed. However, minimum defense frequency (MDF) says you must call at least 50% to prevent their bluffs from being automatically profitable.

questions.question: UTG opens 2.5bb, MP calls. You're on BTN with Th 9h. What's your play?
questions.explanation: T9s has great playability in a multiway pot with position. 3-betting would be a mistake - you'd often face a 4-bet from UTG's strong range or play a bloated pot. By calling, you get great implied odds for straights/flushes and can outplay opponents postflop. This is a speculative hand that thrives in multiway pots.

questions.question: You open BTN with Ad 5d, SB 3-bets to 10bb, BB cold 4-bets to 28bb. What's your play?
questions.explanation: A cold 4-bet from BB over a 3-bet is an extremely strong action - their range is AA, KK, QQ, and maybe AK. Your A5s was a good 3-bet defend candidate against the SB alone, but facing the cold 4-bet you're crushed. You block one ace but that's not enough. Clear fold - even suited wheel aces have limits.

questions.question: You open CO with As Js, BTN 3-bets to 9bb, blinds fold. What's your play at 100bb effective?
questions.explanation: AJs is strong enough to continue against a BTN 3-bet but not quite strong enough to 4-bet. 4-betting turns your hand into a bluff (you fold to a 5-bet) and inflates the pot OOP. By calling, you keep BTN's bluffs in, have good playability with the suited ace, and can realize equity postflop. This is the bread-and-butter of CO vs BTN dynamics.

questions.question: You 3-bet squeeze SB with Ah Kh vs UTG open and BTN call. Both call. Flop: Qc 7h 4h at 25bb effective (short stacked). Pot is 20bb. What's your play?
questions.explanation: At 1.25 SPR with the nut flush draw and two overcards, shoving is correct. You have ~50% equity vs calling ranges and significant fold equity. Betting small commits you anyway and lets opponents realize equity cheaply. Checking gives up fold equity with a hand that wants to maximize it. Short stacks mean draws should be played aggressively.

questions.question: You're 200bb deep in a cash game. You open BTN with Ks Kh, BB 3-bets, you 4-bet, BB calls. Flop: Jc 8s 4c. BB checks. Pot is 40bb, 160bb behind. What's your play?
questions.explanation: When very deep (4:1 SPR), you need to think about the full tree. Large bets commit you to getting stacks in vs BB's 4-bet calling range (JJ, 88, 44, AK, AQ). Small betting lets you control the pot and get two streets of thin value. If raised, you can fold without being committed. Deep stack poker requires smaller, more maneuverable sizings.

questions.question: UTG opens 2.5bb, MP calls, CO calls. You're on BTN with Ac Ts. What's your play?

scenario.action_to_hero: UTG open, MP call, CO call

questions.explanation: This is a classic squeeze spot. The callers have capped ranges and will fold most of their hands to aggression. ATs has solid blockers to strong hands and plays well if called. Squeezing picks up 8bb of dead money frequently and positions you to play in position when called.

questions.question: CO opens 2.5bb, BTN calls. You're in SB with Kc Jc. What's your play?
questions.explanation: KJs is at the top of your SB squeezing range. Calling is terrible - you'd be OOP multiway with a hand that needs to improve. Squeezing generates fold equity against both wide ranges. When called, you have a playable suited broadway with position on BB and initiative. Folding a hand this strong is too passive.

questions.question: You 3-bet BB with Qd Qc vs BTN. BTN calls. Flop: As 8c 3h. What's your play?
questions.explanation: QQ is a significant portion of your checking range on ace-high flops OOP. If you c-bet, you fold out worse hands and only get action from Ax and better. By checking, you can check-call or check-raise based on BTN's action, and you under-represent your hand. BTN will often bet their entire range, letting you extract value from their bluffs.

questions.question: You 3-bet SB with Kd Qs vs CO open. CO calls. Flop: Qh 7c 4d. What's your sizing?
questions.explanation: You have top pair good kicker on a dry board. Unlike ace-high flops, Q-high boards favor your 3-betting range significantly. A larger sizing denies equity from overcards and extracts value from worse queens and draws. Checking would under-represent your strong holding.

questions.question: Villain folds 80% to river bets in single raised pots. You have a pure bluff on the river with a pot-sized bet available. What should you do?
options: Bet because GTO says to balance
questions.explanation: Against a player who overfolds rivers, exploitative strategy demands bluffing more. Your pot-sized bluff needs villain to fold 50% to break even. They fold 80%. This is hugely +EV. GTO only matters against balanced opponents - against exploitable players, maximize EV by attacking their leaks. Here, that means bluffing relentlessly.

questions.question: You open CO with Jd Jh, BTN calls. Flop: 8c 7c 4s. What's your play?
questions.explanation: JJ is a vulnerable overpair on this wet, connected board. Straight draws (T9, 65, 56) and flush draws all have significant equity. You need to charge draws to continue. A larger sizing denies correct odds to draws while extracting value from worse pairs and protecting your equity.
