questions.question: Which hand is correctly part of a typical BB vs SB limping defense range at 100bb?
questions.explanation: When SB limps into you in the BB, you should have a wide raising range but also check some hands to realize equity for free. 72o is too weak to raise for value but can see a flop for free. Folding from BB when you can check is always a mistake. You get to see 5 cards for no additional cost.

questions.question: In your BB defend vs BTN open range at 100bb, which hand type should be the highest frequency 3-bet?
questions.explanation: While premiums are 3-bet, they're few combos. A2s-A5s are the highest frequency 3-bets because: 1) they block AA/AK, 2) they have nut flush potential, 3) they play poorly as flats OOP, 4) there are 16 combos. This is why wheel aces dominate modern BB 3-betting frequencies.

questions.question: BTN opens, you call BB with Ad 9d. Flop: Ts 7h 3c. Check, BTN bets 50%, you call. Turn: 2d. Check, BTN bets 75%, you call. River: Kc. Check, BTN checks. What do you put BTN on most likely?
questions.explanation: BTN bet flop and turn but checked river when the K came. A strong K would value bet the river. A missed draw would often bluff the scare card. Top pair Tx fears the K and might check, but also might thin value bet. 88-99 fits perfectly - they had value on earlier streets but the overcard to the board scared them into checking. This is a classic 'scared of overcards' line.

questions.question: You open CO with As Tc, BTN calls. Flop: Ad Jh 6c. You c-bet 33%, BTN calls. Turn: 7s. What's your play?
questions.explanation: AT is a medium-strength hand - you beat AX worse kickers but lose to AJ, AK, AQ, two pair, and sets. By checking turn, you control the pot and don't inflate it to a size where you're forced to make tough river decisions. You can call a reasonable bet or check through and value bet thin rivers. Betting turns this into a three-street commitment with a hand that doesn't want that.

questions.question: You open CO with Ah Kh, BTN and BB both call. Flop: Qd 8c 4h. BB checks. What's your play?
questions.explanation: In multiway pots, c-bet frequency should drop dramatically. With AK no pair and two opponents, your fold equity is low - at least one player often has a queen or better. Check and realize your backdoor equity. C-betting here burns chips against connected ranges.

questions.question: You open UTG with Ks Kc, MP and BTN call. Flop: Jh 6s 2c. What's your play?
questions.explanation: Unlike AK on a Q-high board, KK on J62 is a clear value bet even multiway. You have a significant overpair on a dry board. Bet for value and protection against Jx, pocket pairs, and overcards. Players with draws and weaker pairs will call.

questions.question: You open BTN with 7s 6s, SB and BB call. Flop: 9s 8d 4s. SB checks, BB bets 75% pot. What's your play?
questions.explanation: You have a flush draw (9 outs), open-ended straight draw (8 outs minus overlaps), for ~15 outs twice - a monster draw with ~55% equity. With SB still to act and BB's donk bet showing strength, raising semi-bluffs generates fold equity, builds the pot for when you hit, and protects against SB's overcards. Calling is too passive with this equity.

questions.question: You open CO with Ad Jd, BB calls. Flop: Tc 7c 3h. BB leads out for 33% pot. What's your play?
questions.explanation: A small donk bet is often a weak probe or draw. AJ has two overcards and backdoor potential. Folding is too tight - you have equity and position. Raising turns your hand into a bluff against a range that includes strong hands. Call, use position, and re-evaluate the turn.

questions.question: You open BTN with Qc Qd, BB calls. Flop: Ac Kh 7s. BB leads for 80% pot. What's your play?
questions.explanation: A large donk bet on AK7 is polarized and usually strong. BB's range for this sizing is Ax, Kx, sets, and two pair. Your QQ loses to all value and barely beats the few bluffs (which wouldn't use this sizing). Calling chases two outs. Discipline fold despite your preflop premium.

questions.question: You call BTN open from BB with Kc Tc. Flop: Qh Jc 4c. Check, BTN bets 50%, you call. Turn: 6d. Check, BTN bets 66%, you call. River: 2h. Pot is 18bb, you have 65bb. What's your play?
questions.explanation: You have K-high with a missed flush draw. You have no showdown value and minimal fold equity against a double-barrel range. BTN likely has Qx or better to barrel twice. Bluffing is unprofitable - they're not folding value on a dry runout. Check and fold to a bet.

questions.question: You 3-bet CO from BTN with As 4s, CO calls. Flop: Kh 7s 3s. You bet 33%, CO calls. Turn: Jd. You bet 66%, CO calls. River: Qc. Pot is 35bb, you have 55bb. What's your play?
questions.explanation: The Q completes the broadway straight for AT. You've represented strength throughout and the Q is a great scare card. CO's double-calling range is Kx, Jx, and floats - none of which can call a river shove comfortably. Your As blocks nut flush draws they might have had. This is a high-equity bluff spot.

questions.question: You defend BB with Jh Th vs CO open. Flop: Kc 9h 2h. You check, CO bets 33%. What's your play?
questions.explanation: You have a flush draw (9 outs) plus gutshot (3-4 more outs) - a premium semi-bluff. Against a small c-bet, CO's range is wide with many folds. Check-raising generates fold equity while building a pot for when you hit. Your hand is too strong to just call and too weak to slowplay.

questions.question: You defend BB with 5d 4d vs BTN open. Flop: As 6h 3c. You check, BTN bets 25%. What's your play?
questions.explanation: You have an open-ended straight draw on a dry ace-high board. BTN's 25% c-bet indicates range betting - they'll have many weak hands. Check-raising represents an ace strongly and folds out hands like KQ, QJ, pocket pairs that have equity against you. With 8 outs and fold equity, this is a profitable semi-bluff.

questions.question: Why is it critical to 3-bet wider from the SB vs late position opens compared to BB?
options: SB posts less money than BB
SB can fold postflop more easily
SB is OOP to everyone including BB who gets good odds to call
SB has stronger hands on average
questions.answer: SB is OOP to everyone including BB who gets good odds to call
questions.explanation: From SB, if you flat, BB gets great odds to overcall (already has 1bb in) and you'll play multiway OOP to both. This is disastrous for equity realization. By 3-betting, you either take it down or get heads-up vs the original raiser with initiative. The positional disadvantage makes flatting from SB a major leak.

questions.question: In a BTN vs BB single raised pot, approximately what percentage of flops should BTN c-bet if using a range c-bet strategy?
questions.explanation: BTN has significant range and positional advantage vs BB in SRPs. On most board textures, BTN can c-bet their entire range with small sizing (25-33% pot) profitably. The 70-80% figure accounts for some boards where checking back is correct (monotone, very connected). This high-frequency small-bet strategy is a cornerstone of modern poker.

questions.question: You have Ac As on a flop of 9h 7c 5s heads-up as the preflop raiser. Why is betting preferable to checking?
options: To deny equity from overcards and draws
Because checking is never correct with aces
questions.answer: To deny equity from overcards and draws
questions.explanation: AA is vulnerable on coordinated boards. Hands like JT, QT, 86, and any two Broadway cards have significant equity against you (20-30%). By betting, you charge these draws incorrect prices and often get them to fold, denying their equity. Checking gives free cards to hands that can outdraw you.

questions.question: On a river with a polarized range (nuts or air), why is overbetting often superior to standard sizing?
options: It maximizes value from strong hands and fold equity with bluffs
questions.answer: It maximizes value from strong hands and fold equity with bluffs
questions.explanation: When polarized, you either have the nuts (want maximum value) or air (want maximum fold equity). A pot-sized or smaller bet doesn't maximize either. Overbetting extracts more from their calling range with your value hands while making their bluff-catchers unprofitable to call with your bluffs. It's mathematically optimal when truly polarized.

questions.question: River: Ah Kd Qc 9s 4h. You have JT (nut straight). Villain checks. Why might betting small be superior to a large bet?
options: You hold blockers to straights, so villain is polarized toward Ax and bluffs
Small bets always get more calls
Large bets only work as bluffs
questions.answer: You hold blockers to straights, so villain is polarized toward Ax and bluffs
questions.explanation: You block the nut straight (JT) and villain checked river - they likely don't have it. Their range is primarily Ax (value hands to call small) or air (won't call any size). A small bet extracts max value from their Ax that would fold to overbets. Your blockers mean large sizing targets a non-existent calling range.

questions.question: You're considering bluffing the river. You have Ad 2d on a board with three diamonds. Why might this be a poor bluff choice?
options: Your Ad blocks villain's bluffs and your 2d blocks their weak flushes
Two pair is never a good bluff
questions.answer: Your Ad blocks villain's bluffs and your 2d blocks their weak flushes
questions.explanation: When bluffing, you want to block villain's value hands (so they fold) not their bluffs (which would fold anyway). A2dd on a flushed board blocks both: Ad blocks flush draws they'd be bluffing with, and the flush itself blocks their weak flushes that might fold. Ideal bluffs have cards that block their value, not their air.

questions.question: You open BTN with Kh Td, BB calls. Board: Kc 9s 5d 3h 2c. You bet flop, check turn, BB checks. What's your river play?
questions.explanation: BB's range after checking twice is capped - no Kx or strong 9x. Their range is small pairs, missed draws, and floats. Your KT can extract thin value from 9x, pocket pairs like 77-88, and Ax floats that might call small. A small sizing gets called by these weaker holdings without over-representing.

questions.question: CO opens, you call BTN with Qs Jc. Flop: Qh 8d 3c. CO bets 33%, you call. Turn: 5h. CO bets 66%, you call. River: Ah. CO shoves 120% pot. What's your play?
questions.explanation: The Ah is a scare card but CO's line is suspicious. Would they really shove a rivered ace or AQ for value? Those hands would typically bet smaller. The overbet shove screams polarization between sets/two pair and bluffs. Your QJ beats all their bluffs. Given pot odds (need ~45% equity) and CO's bluff-heavy tendencies in this spot, call.

questions.question: You 3-bet BB with Ah Jh vs BTN open. BTN calls. Flop: Jc 7s 4h. You bet 33%, BTN calls. Turn: 2d. You check, BTN bets 75%. What's your play?
questions.explanation: Your turn check showed weakness and BTN attacked. But AJ is top pair top kicker - folding is way too weak. Check-raising is unnecessary and only gets action from better. BTN could have JT, J9, overpairs, or pure bluffs attacking your check. Call and evaluate the river. You have a clear bluff-catcher.

questions.question: You 3-bet CO vs UTG open with As Qh. UTG calls. Flop: Kd 7c 2h. You c-bet 33%, UTG calls. Turn: Ts. What's your play?
questions.explanation: The T gives you a gutshot to the nuts (J = broadway) and your range still has significant equity here. UTG's flop-calling range is capped - most Kx would 4-bet pre or check-raise flop. Continuing aggression represents KK/AA/AK and folds out pocket pairs and weaker draws. The T hits your 3-bet range well.

questions.question: You open BTN with 6c 5c, SB 3-bets, you call. Flop: 8c 7h 2c. SB bets 33%, you call. Turn: Ad. SB checks. What's your play?
questions.explanation: SB's check on the A is weakness - they'd almost always continue with AA, AK, AQ. Their range is now QQ-JJ, KK (scared of A), or missed c-bets. You have an OESD plus flush draw - 15 outs. A large bet represents the ace and generates significant fold equity while building a pot for when you hit. SB is folding overpairs here often.

questions.question: 200bb deep. You open BTN with Kd Kc, BB 3-bets, you 4-bet, BB calls. Flop: 7h 6h 5h. BB donk shoves for ~1.5x pot. What's your play?
questions.explanation: This is a sickening spot but a fold. BB's 4-bet calling range is AA, KK, QQ, AK, maybe JJ. On a monotone connected board, their donk shove is extremely polarized. The only bluff is AhXh but that has huge equity. Their value range (sets, Ah with pair, made flush) crushes your one-pair hand. Even with KK, you're drawing nearly dead against their realistic range.

questions.question: You have an open-ended straight draw on the turn (8 outs). Pot is 15bb, villain bets 10bb. Should you call?
options: Yes, if implied odds are good
It depends on the river card
questions.answer: Yes, if implied odds are good
questions.explanation: You need to call 10bb to win 25bb = 40% equity needed. With 8 outs you have ~17% (8/46) to hit. Pure pot odds say fold. However, with implied odds (how much you'll win when you hit), calling can be profitable if villain will pay off a significant bet on the river. This is a common spot to consider stack depths.

questions.question: Villain is all-in. The pot is 50bb and you need to call 30bb with a combo draw (flush + gutshot = 12 outs). The turn is out. Is this a call?
questions.explanation: You need to call 30bb to win 80bb = 37.5% equity needed. With 12 outs on the turn, you have roughly 12 × 2.2 = 26% to hit by the river. Wait - that's not enough by rule of 2. But the rule of 4 applies since you see both cards: 12 × 4 = 48%. Since villain is all-in, you see both cards with guaranteed equity realization. 48% > 37.5%. Call.

questions.question: UTG raises, you 3-bet MP with QQ, UTG 4-bets small (2.2x your 3-bet). What does this sizing typically indicate?
options: UTG has AA/KK and wants a call
UTG has AK and is unsure
questions.answer: UTG has AA/KK and wants a call
questions.explanation: A small 4-bet sizing (often called a 'clickback' or 'milking' 4-bet) typically indicates extreme strength. With AA/KK, UTG wants to keep you in and build the pot. With a bluff or medium hand, they'd usually size larger to generate fold equity or just call. This small 4-bet is a trap line - proceed with caution.

questions.question: You're on the BTN. MP opens, you 3-bet, MP calls. Flop: Ad Kc Qc (you have JTs). MP check-raises your c-bet. What hands is MP most likely representing?
questions.explanation: On AKQ with a flush draw, MP's check-raise is most naturally the nuts (JT for Broadway) or a combo draw. Sets wouldn't typically check-raise this wet board - they'd call and let you barrel into their trap. AK would play similarly. The most common check-raise line here is made straight or strong semi-bluff with club draws.

questions.question: You open HJ with Tc 9c, CO calls. Flop: Jh 8c 4d. You c-bet 33%, CO raises to 3x. What's your play?
questions.explanation: You have an open-ended straight draw (8 outs) plus backdoor flush draw. CO's raise could be value (JT+, sets) or semi-bluff (draws, 98). Folding 8 outs with backdoors is too tight. 3-betting turns your hand into a bluff when you have good equity to realize. Call and hit your draw.

questions.question: You defend BB with Ah 4h vs BTN open. Flop: Ks 9h 6h. Check, BTN bets 75%. What's your play?
questions.explanation: The nut flush draw is extremely valuable but check-raising against a large sizing is risky - you'll face a 3-bet often with significant equity denied. Calling keeps the pot manageable, disguises your hand, and lets you stack villain when you hit. Check-raising is higher variance without enough fold equity against this sizing.

questions.question: You open CO with As Js, BTN calls. Flop: Ac 8h 5c. You c-bet 33%, BTN calls. Turn: 2d. What's your play?
questions.explanation: You have top pair good kicker. BTN flatted a small c-bet with a range of weak aces, club draws, and middle pairs. The 2d changes nothing. Continue betting for value - worse aces and all draws call. Checking lets them realize free equity and misses value from hands that would fold to a second barrel.

questions.question: You open BTN with Jh Jd, SB 3-bets, you call. Flop: Ts 6s 3c. SB bets 66%. What's your play?
questions.explanation: JJ is an overpair on a board that doesn't hit SB's 3-betting range hard (no AK, AQ connections). You beat all their bluffs and many value bets (TT, 99). Folding is way too weak. Raising bloats the pot when you're often against overpairs that have you crushed. Call and evaluate the turn.

questions.question: You defend BB with 8c 7c vs CO open. Board runs out: 9c 6h 2d - 5c - Ac. You check-called flop, check-called turn. River Ac completes backdoor flush and you made your straight. CO checks. What's your play?
questions.explanation: You have the 2nd nuts (9-high straight loses only to T8). CO's check indicates weakness - they likely have a pair or missed draw. An overbet maximizes value from their Ax that might hero-call and prices out any consideration of bluff-raising. Your range is super strong here after the passive line - they'll pay.

questions.question: You 3-bet SB with Kc Qc vs BTN open, BTN calls. Flop: Qh 7s 4d. You bet 33%, BTN calls. Turn: 3c. You bet 66%, BTN calls. River: 8h. What's your play?
questions.explanation: You have top pair second kicker. BTN called two streets - their range is Qx, 77, slow-played sets, and stubborn floats. Your KQ beats all Qx except AQ (rare given no 4-bet). Value bet confidently - 66% extracts from QJ, QT, Q9 and doesn't over-commit. Checking misses significant value.

questions.question: You're in the BB with Ah 7h. CO opens 2.5bb, BTN calls. SB folds. What's your play?
questions.explanation: A7s is playable multiway with its suited ace potential but not strong enough to 3-bet against a CO open with a caller. 3-betting would isolate you against stronger ranges. Calling closes the action with good pot odds (need to call 1.5bb to win ~7bb) and lets you realize equity in a multiway pot where suited aces perform well.

questions.question: UTG opens 2.5bb, you're in MP with Ac Kd. What's your play at 60bb effective (short-stacked)?
questions.explanation: At 60bb, AKo is too strong to flat (plays poorly multiway OOP) but shoving is unnecessarily risky when you have fold equity with a standard 3-bet. 3-betting to ~3x the open size generates fold equity against weaker opens and sets up a comfortable SPR if called. If 4-bet, you can evaluate - AK has the equity to get in at 60bb.

questions.question: You're on the BTN with 6h 5h. UTG opens 2.5bb, MP 3-bets to 8bb. What's your play?
questions.explanation: 65s needs multiway action and good implied odds. Facing a 3-bet with UTG still to act is the worst possible spot - you'll often face a 4-bet or play heads-up OOP against a strong range. Even if you call, UTG might squeeze. Suited connectors thrive in single-raised multiway pots, not 3-bet scenarios.

questions.question: Which of these hands should be in your CO opening range but NOT in your UTG opening range at 100bb 6-max?
questions.explanation: AQo, JTs, and 99 are all standard opens from both UTG and CO. K9s is the marginal hand - from UTG it's too weak (dominated by AK, KQ, KJ when called) but from CO with only 3 players behind, it's a profitable open. This illustrates how position widens your range.

questions.question: In a BB vs BTN 3-bet pot, which hand category should comprise the largest portion of BB's checking range on a Kh 7c 2d flop?
questions.explanation: On dry K-high boards as the OOP 3-bettor, your Kx hands (KQ, KJ) are often better as checks than bets. They're strong enough to call down but not strong enough to build a big pot. AA/QQ prefer betting for protection. Underpairs can mix. This is why Kx dominates the checking range - they want pot control and to induce.

questions.question: What does 'capped range' mean in poker terminology?
options: A range with a maximum number of combos
A range that cannot contain the nuts or very strong hands
questions.answer: A range that cannot contain the nuts or very strong hands
questions.explanation: A capped range is one where the player's previous actions have removed strong hands from their possible holdings. For example, if BTN checks back a coordinated flop, their range is capped - they would have bet sets and strong draws. Recognizing capped ranges lets you apply pressure with bluffs.

questions.question: You're deciding whether to use a 'merged' or 'polarized' c-bet strategy on a flop. Which board texture favors a merged (linear) strategy?
questions.explanation: Merged strategies work on boards where medium-strength hands can value bet and expect calls from worse. AK7 favors the preflop raiser heavily - you can bet Ax, Kx, and even some Qx for thin value because villain's range is weak. On wet/connected boards, medium hands can't value bet safely and polarized strategies (nuts or air) are superior.

questions.question: Why should your BTN flatting range vs CO open be relatively wide?
options: Because you have position on everyone postflop
questions.answer: Because you have position on everyone postflop
questions.explanation: Position lets you see opponent actions before deciding, control pot size, and bluff more effectively. From BTN vs CO, you're guaranteed position postflop, so hands that play well with position (suited connectors, suited aces, broadway) can flat profitably. You'll outplay opponents on later streets.

questions.question: In a HJ vs BB single raised pot, why does HJ have less of a c-betting advantage than BTN vs BB?
options: HJ's range is narrower so the equity advantage is smaller
questions.answer: HJ's range is narrower so the equity advantage is smaller
questions.explanation: HJ opens a tighter range than BTN (more premiums, fewer weak hands). This means on most boards, HJ's range advantage over BB is smaller - BB's defending range hits boards almost as well. BTN's wide opens create huge equity edges on many textures. This is why optimal c-bet frequency decreases as open position moves earlier.

questions.question: You open BTN with 8c 8d, SB 3-bets to 10bb. At what stack depth does calling become better than folding?
options: Fold at all depths vs SB 3-bet
questions.explanation: Pocket pairs need set mining odds - roughly 15:1 implied odds to call for set value. At 80bb+, you can win ~75bb when you hit a set (8x your call of ~9bb). Shorter stacks don't offer enough implied odds. 88 also has some playability but against SB's polar 3-bet range OOP, set mining math drives the decision.

questions.question: You have Qh Qd on a board of As Kd 7c 4h 2s after check-calling flop and turn. Villain bets 50% pot on the river. What category is your hand?
questions.explanation: QQ on AK742 is a classic bluff catcher. You beat all of villain's bluffs (missed draws, floats, pure air) but lose to all their value (Ax, Kx, sets, two pair). The decision isn't about whether your hand is 'good' - it's about whether villain is bluffing frequently enough relative to their bet size.

questions.question: You're in BB with 4h 4d. Board: 4c 9s 7h Jd Ks after you check-raised flop, bet turn, and now face a river shove from BTN. Pot was 25bb, BTN shoved 60bb. What's your play?
questions.explanation: You have bottom set - one of the strongest hands possible. The board ran out with no flush and only JT makes a straight. BTN's shove could be a higher set (99, 77 - you block neither), J9, K9, or a bluff. Given you showed strength and they're shoving huge, they could be turning a hand like KJ into a bluff. Bottom set can't fold in this spot.

questions.question: You open CO with Ah 9h, BTN calls. Flop: Ac 6c 3s. You bet 33%, BTN calls. Turn: Tc. You bet 50%, BTN raises to 2.5x. What's your play?
questions.explanation: A9 is top pair with a decent kicker. BTN's turn raise could be value (AT, A6, sets, two pair, flush) or semi-bluff (club draws, 98cc type hands). Folding top pair to one raise is too weak. 3-bet shoving bloats the pot when you're often behind or flipping. Call and evaluate the river - you can fold to aggression or call down.

questions.question: Villain check-raises the flop 35% of the time (very high frequency). How should you adjust your c-betting strategy?
options: C-bet more frequently with strong hands only
C-bet less frequently overall, check back more medium hands
Always c-bet and call the raise
questions.answer: C-bet less frequently overall, check back more medium hands
questions.explanation: Against a high check-raise frequency, your c-bets get punished often. Adjust by: 1) checking back more medium-strength hands that hate raises, 2) c-betting only strong hands and select bluffs, 3) calling raises more liberally since their range is wider/bluffier. This narrows your c-bet range and protects your checking range.

questions.question: Villain folds to 3-bets 75% of the time. What adjustment maximizes your profit?
options: 3-bet only premium hands for max value
3-bet extremely wide with any two cards
3-bet wider but maintain some value range
questions.answer: 3-bet wider but maintain some value range
questions.explanation: At 75% fold, 3-betting is immediately profitable with any two cards. However, the 25% of the time they call/4-bet, you need some value. Exploit by 3-betting very wide (including suited junk that plays OK if called) but keep premium hands for value when they continue. Pure any-two-cards 3-betting leaves you crushed when they fight back.

questions.question: You want to get 100bb stacks in over 3 streets. Pot is 10bb on the flop. What sizing on each street accomplishes this geometrically?
questions.explanation: Geometric growth: Starting with 10bb pot, betting 75% each street grows the pot optimally. Flop: 10bb + 7.5bb call = 25bb. Turn: 25bb + 18.75bb = 62.5bb. River: 62.5bb + ~47bb = shove ~100bb remaining. Three 75% pot bets is roughly geometric for getting stacks in over three streets at 100bb depth.

questions.question: You open CO with Kh Jh, BB calls. Flop: Kd 9c 5h. BB donks 50% pot. What's your play?
questions.explanation: You have top pair good kicker. A donk bet often indicates a marginal made hand or draw testing the waters. Raising would only get action from better (K9, KQ, sets) and fold out bluffs. By calling, you keep in their weaker range and can extract value on later streets. Evaluate based on turn action.
